utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino, along with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters and Greg Gutfeld. It's 9 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." President Trump today fulfilled a controversial and major campaign promise by pulling the United States out of the landmark Paris climate agreement. The climate pack seeks to reduce the amount of worldwide pollution emissions. But the president said it imposes far too heavy a burden on America's economy and that it's unfair to America's workers.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: As of today, the United States will cease all implementation of the non-biding Paris accord and the draconian financial and economic burdens the agreement imposes on our country, global activists that have long sort to gain wealth at our country's expense. They don't put America first. I do. And I always will. I was elected to represent the citizens of Pittsburgh, not Paris. Our withdrawal from the agreement represents a reassertion of America's sovereignty.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Trump did say that the U.S. would potentially reenter the agreement if its administration can negotiate a better deal. So Jesse --

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- this is a big deal today. This is like Kyoto and all sort of things all rolled into one, kaboom.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All -- kaboom is right, that's the less reaction if you listen to the television today. I mean, we went from leading from behind to America first today. Let's remember this Paris deal was negotiated by none other than Barack Obama, not the best dealmaker if you look at Bergdahl, Obamacare and the Iran deal. So anything he does is suspect. So, I don't know if he got hoodwinked or he wanted to knock America down to size. But, it caused $3 trillion and you lose 6 million jobs. And to, what, hypothetically bring the temperature down a fraction of a degree in 100 years seems pretty stupid to me. And, India and China, they can continue to push coal, they receive taxpayer money, and they can increase emissions. Meanwhile, we can't do any of that. So it doesn't make a lot of sense to me. I think spreading the wealth schemes don't work. If they did, Venezuela would be a paradise. Obviously, it's not capitalism works. Trump said something very specific. He loves the American worker. There's nothing wrong with that. And I think Democrats used to understand that, they don't anymore. He's not beholden to foreign capitals, he's beholding to the constitution. If Obama wanted this done, he would've sent it to the Senate for ratification. You know, Democrats can't control their emotions, let alone the temperature in 100 years. The same people that were saying Hillary was going to be elected in November are telling us what the weather is going be like. I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Interesting that -- something happened today Greg, along the waves of this announcement which was at federalism (ph) started working because a bunch of cities and states, mayors and governors and then you have big corporations saying, "Well, we're going to take it upon ourselves to, you know, ratchet down on emissions anyway." So, if they're going to do that, maybe you don't need the federal government to push.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Exactly. The government -- hey, wait, if the government is not going to force us, we'll do it ourselves.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go. That's called conservatism, everybody.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Free markets, OK. This is an interesting decision, what he did because he didn't actually have to do this. In fact, I think this might be the bravest thing he's done. He's already expended a lot of political capital. He's not very popular. He could have gotten strange new respect from the left by letting this go. He could have agreed with his daughter. It's a non-binding agreement, which means it really is useless and also it's a bad deal. It's a -- as Jesse pointed out, it's so absurdly expensive for a negligible increase. Up to $200 trillion over a century will cut 1 percent of the carbon target, which is a 2 Celsius reduction in global temperature. So, in order to reach their ideal, you would need to multiply 200 trillion by 100 trillion or something like 200 by 100, which we don't even have. So it's carbon cutting is a farce. The impact of this deal is negligible, but it will destroy economies. So, what he did was actually brave in the sense that he didn't have to do it, he could've just not followed through. Now, you're watching everybody going crazy over this. All he said was, it's a bad deal. If it becomes a better deal, I'll go in. He's like the guy who walked into the showroom and said -- he looked at the car, he says, "That's too expensive. You know what, give me a call, I'll come back." That's exactly what he did. Or another metaphor is, he went to a party, realized the party sucked, and said, "I don't need to be here. Maybe there's a better party." So the idea that this is somehow an awful thing is hysterical. If you're going to lose your crap over this, you are lying, you're a liar. This is not bad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And to that point, Kimberly, some --

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- proponent said that you -- you know, "You just stay in, President Trump, because you don't have to abide by it." So, is it better to sit at the table and fake it -- like, for example, Governor Schwarzenegger one time came to the White House and he told President Bush, "Sir, you don't have to actually believe in climate change. You just have to say that you do and then everybody will like you." And he's like, "Oh, really, is that how that works?"

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think that President Trump, like I said last night, was being very consistent with this campaign promise. He promised that he was going to do this. I don't think this is a deal that anybody should be crying about. Like we said, it's nonbinding. And the United States is already a clean energy, oil and gas leader. So, we can keep doing what we're doing. We can keep reducing our admissions. Why would we, in fact, put ourselves at an economic disadvantage, giving and subsidizing an economic windfall to other countries and sort of a climate redistribution of wealth scheme? It makes no sense to me. I think he did the brave and courageous thing. And in fact, I told him that this morning at 8:00 a.m. when he called. And I spoke to him about it. And this was something very much so on his mind. And -- but he seems like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, who called you?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The president.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: To ask about climate change?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why did he call? He calls you?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Climate change, taxes --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think they bury the lede --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- "The Five."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right, she tried to slip that in there.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Maybe it happens all the time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that is to say, yes, you know, the president called me at 8 o'clock in the morning.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's not unknown, I thought it was Fox News. But then he said he loves "The Five", terrific show, said to say hello to all of your guest. Like the covfefe (ph), exactly.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Oh, my covfefe, he said.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He was excited about this today, it was going to be a big feature, a lot of people will be excited about it. However, there will be people that will be upset and disappointed. He was doing his best, you know, to explain.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like this one over here.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, like Juan. But then again --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, did anybody call you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, it was so private. I wouldn't -- at 8:00, I'm snoozing, dude. I dreamt about it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But you can have the floor, Juan, because I'm sure you have a lot to say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I do, because I'm such a liar, I'm a liar according to Gregory. But I tell you what, I don't have to participate in this partisan bickering because the United States is the only country where there's this kind of political polarization over the idea of climate change. The rest of the world? Oh, no, we know something's going on. Why? 2016, the warmest year in history. Third (ph) year in a row that we set this record, according to NASA, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Gee, I don't think these people are too political. But guess what --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is that what -- is Trump disputing the sides?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes. Because --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's a difference.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, there is no difference.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: (Inaudible) a reality. If you put on blinders and say, "Don't pay attention to the fact that we have --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Coast deniers, coast deniers.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- coast rising, coastal water is rising. Don't pay any attention to the polar ice caps. Just ignore it." You know who couldn't ignore it? Rex Tillerson, secretary of state. Not there. Ivanka? Oh my gosh, the darling child.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: June (ph) holiday.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The June holiday, there's the --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's an excuse. And let me just tell you something up.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Juan, I don't think you should demean as (inaudible) --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just telling you it was an excuse.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- explanation and it a White House statement issues about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And let me tell you something else.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh my goodness (ph).

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You have Jeff Immelt of G.E. so you go, Oh, this is about jobs, get out of here.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: G.E., Shell, ExxonMobil.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, wait, you had the floor, buddy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Elon Musk says --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- I'm not even doing business with Trump anymore, and he was on Trump's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But still take Trump's money, right?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's our money.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So here's the deal. You have bunch of people who are Trump puppets sitting around here --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Ask him if he's done with his (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- that the United States would suddenly advocate all leadership and let China and let the Europeans take the lead from --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You told me don't listen to NASA and the national --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, NASA's problems.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, NASA has -- attack NASA, go right ahead. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Both the national corporations --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- like ExxonMobil and Shell want these deals because they can sign these fat contracts with these third-world countries --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I see.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- that get paid off of U.S. taxpayer subsidies. Number two, of course, China wants this deal. They get to do whatever they want. And they get to knock America down to size.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When did he follow what China wants?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what happened today? The French president spoke --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And you know what he said?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because -- Greg says, is "Oh, Trump is just doing the --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: According to Greg, Trump is just saying this party sucks, I can get a better party or I can get a cheaper price on the car. You what the president of France said? Forget it, buddy. No renegotiation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, we don't listen to the French.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I see.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: During World War II.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I see, oh, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Plus, how was the 6 million jobs lost and $3 trillion --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- is set. How do you think that's a good deal? Trump is not anti science, he's anti bad deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Hey, can I --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: 3.1 manufacturing sector jobs is lost (ph).

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: People agree that this -- the reason why it was nonbinding was because it was understandable if he didn't want to be part of it, because he was putting so much -- so many burdens on so many countries. So why is it popular among the famous and the rich? It's because it's a gesture of benevolence that gives them the immunity for their behavior. So you can have your private jets and you can have your limos, and you can have your 8,000 square foot that was just -- home that was just purchased in Chicago, I believe, or was it D.C., I'm not sure, by President Obama. This deal was useless. But how did it get this far? Because it was designed to punish the west. Environmental activism is designed to seek reparations for the west's past. So you don't -- it doesn't matter if the deal is flawed. It doesn't matter if, economically, it is impossible. It doesn't matter because we are sinners and this is their way of punishing us. And finally, somebody said, "You know what, screw you, Paris. We're not taking it. Maybe we can fix it. We'll talk later. But right now, it's not going to work." What is wrong with that? And by the way, Juan, he's not denying the science. He's looking at the economics. The economics is absolutely mind- bogglingly -- it's absurd.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'll tell you what's absurd. What's so rude to me is he goes and meets with the pope. The pope hands him an encyclical on environmental concerns and climate change. He's, "Oh, I'm going to listen, Mr. Pope." He goes right, you talk about jobs --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was awesome.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't bring the pope into this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If the kind of rules that Trump is perpetrating on the coal miners in this country tell, "Oh, yes, this is for you coal miners, get out of town", there's not one cold job is going to come back because of this deal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're opening a new mine up next week, Juan, because --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, there are going to be more --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This deal is (inaudible) capitates the coal industry which provides --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But the coal industry --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, we got to run.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you tell coal miners that he's ought to work --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Hey, you guys, so we have a whole another block to do on this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But no, personally that's -- you know what really helps clean up the country? Natural gas, nuclear power. You know who's against it? Environmentalists.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And if a deal can get everybody but Syria and (inaudible) on it, is it really just symbolic anyway to your point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, in the next hour, you're going to hear more from the White House on the president's decision to withdraw America from the climate pack, because Vice President Mike Pence joins Sean Hannity. Tune in at 10:00 p.m. But first, some wild reactions from the left to Mr. Trump's controversial action today, highlights, next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. The left's reaction to President Trump's withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement was immediate and fierce.

utterances.speaker: FAREED ZAKARIA, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: This will be the day the United States resign as the leader of the free world. It's nothing short of that. DONNY DEUTSCH, EXECUTIVE & TELEVISION PERSONALITY: I have such rage and sadness. We just watched a dangerous little man give a very, very scary speech.

utterances.speaker: JOHN KERRY, FORMER SECRETARY OF STATE
utterances.utterance: He's made us an environmental pariah in the world. And I think it is one of the most self-destructive moves I've ever seen by any president in my lifetime.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wow. Lunatics. And celebrities also bashed Trump for it, leading the climate deal on Twitter. Bette Midler wrote, "There has never in U.S. history been such a destructive megalomaniac in the White House. Thank you to U.S press and other numbskulls who put him there. I mean, wow. There are no words. A very upset Leonardo DiCaprio probably tweeting from his Tesla wrote, "Today, our planet suffered. It's more important than ever to take action #ParisAgreement." And singer John Legend pulled no punches when he posted, "Trump is our national embarrassment." I mean, do you think any of these people read this, Greg, and have any understanding of the topic?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's so beautiful. It just makes me realize how right the decision was when you see these people that are about, you know, 1 centimeter deep in substance.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, underneath all of this outrage, it isn't reason. It's emotion because non-binding agreement, no big deal. The results are negligible but very costly. So it's a bad deal.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, it's not based on reason but it's based on emotion. So why are they so emotionally invested in this? It's because the guilt industrial complex, which has been part of the liberal ethos for the past four decades and kept America feeling guilty about everything, didn't work this time. We decided, "No, we're not going to go and get involved in this lame party because we're not guilty. We don't have to do this." So what you're seeing are a bunch of people realizing that their superpower is fading. They had this magical gift to make us feel guilty and the president just gave them the old --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can I disagree slightly --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- with you?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Is that I think that, yes, they're -- if they're showing passion but it's fake.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But partly because when this agreement was signed, the left, in particular, was not happy with it and said it was toothless. It wasn't -- didn't go far enough. It wasn't -- if you look at Jim Hansen, he was the NASA scientist who caused all the problems during the Bush administration about climate. He said that it was one of the worst things that President Obama could have done with answering to this thing that it would had no -- it would actually achieve nothing. So, I actually think that part of it on the celebrity side of things is there -- this actually fuels their ability to continue to make money on this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Look at the grants, and the speeches, and the conferences and the concerts, like all that stuff is going to be able to continue and they'll use this decision as a way to do it. Now --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's also -- it's for the career, too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Think about this, if President Trump had made the decision to stay in, which I think you could have defended as well, they would say, "Yes, but that's not enough." And the vitriol would have been the same.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Dana, I think you're right. People were upset and said how bad Comey was, they said how bad this agreement was. And then, he does something about it, they don't like it because it's President Trump who's making this decision.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They said it wasn't bad enough.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And by the way, people like yourself, Juan, would be saying, "Oh, if he went ahead with this and didn't rescind it and withdraw the United States", or, "Oh, look at him flip-flopping --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, they would have said (inaudible) the decision because it's not binding and --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- really doesn't have -- he really doesn't have to do anything here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Excuse me, but I think that -- he just flip-flopped today on Jerusalem, right?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He flip-flopped on NASA, right? I mean, he flip-flopped on --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- right? Oh no, but not on this one. Oh, I see, I get it. But let me say to all of this. I find -- you know, maybe when there's that sinkhole in front of Mar-a-Lago turns into a swamp, maybe the thing is, oh, yes, yes, I should have --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Then he'll drain it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I got -- yes, he'll drain it for himself but not for us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Every climate prediction has been wrong.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, I tell you what --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Everyone has been wrong because --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, no, no, I am right. I am right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, you are so wrong.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, dude, you don't even read this crap. You get the crap from the media. That's where you get it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, you know where you it get from?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Where?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You get it from Breitbart. You get it from the far right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That is what -- this is what --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just tell you something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what you read?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You read the talking points from Media Matters.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And Breitbart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What? I don't even read that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because you know what?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because if you're -- Greg, if you're a good -- and libertarian, in your case, oh, you got to be opposed to this.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. Juan, don't you find that to be a little arrogant.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, let me finish the point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I gave you the economics in the A block (ph).

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh my gosh, here we go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Three quarters of the American people --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Put the timer on it. It's just on and on, on and on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Put the timer on because three quarters of the American people say that they expect as a result of climate change, there've been a damage to the coastal water --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a poll based on media hysteria.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is not a fact.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: (Inaudible) like the American people --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: (Inaudible) interpretation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- are stupid. The American people are crazy. Only Greg is right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, Juan, you know what you're doing, you're twisting it. You're taking a poll that is based on people people's attitudes from media coverage.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And you're putting that into a fact, that's not a fact, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh yes, and the whole argument about nationalism, and this is going to help workers --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't say that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, it comes from you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I didn't say that. I didn't even question --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In the Breitbart and the right-wing talk radio.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But no --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, hold on a second.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- you were in tuning (ph) me. I didn't say that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, what did he say?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Greg is actually very learneth and --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh yes, he is.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- I have to say an expert on climate change.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He went to Berkeley. He went to Berkeley.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I actually read this stuff, Juan. I read it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was an honorary degree.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Here we go, it's an --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I read it, I don't stout it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Bottom line is, Juan, I take issue with it because you're casting these dispersions against Greg and disparaging him and --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- it's totally unfounded.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, you're questioning whether I did my research.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Of course, I do. But I'm telling you --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He doesn't read talking points from Breitbart.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Sorry to tell you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- I think NASA is a talking point --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm telling -- you said that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I see.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You said that he gets talking points from Breitbart --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Explain to me any study you've read.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Give me a break.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Explain to me the consensus reports that you've read. Or the IPTT reports or any of that stuff. Explain to me -- or anything that you have read beyond a poll of people who have just read secondary reports from the press.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I just --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who are biased.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I -- oh, I don't think that the scientists in the National Atmospheric --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you know anything about Hansen at all? Do you know anything?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I read -- because you know what, you told me about a year ago, go read about it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And what did you find out about Hansen?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, no --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's he's incredibly controversial.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That he's involved to a lot of problems.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I also found out that there's no question about the consensus that you doubt about scientists.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what, where's the consensus from?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I see.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's based on two general questions (ph) --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, there we go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- done by a grad student.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's right, you want to undermine anything that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's called reading.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I see.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Reading is undermining.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Please.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Jesse Watters, you have the floor.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow, I mean, the only temperatures rising right over here and here, I don't really know what to say. I mean, the only thing I can say to you, Juan, is that --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's a Chinese hoax.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a Chinese hoax, and it's perpetrated by --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But in all seriousness, you know, they're saying that Trump is going to kill people in 100 years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, look, I --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, you had the floor.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're saying Trump was going to kill people maybe in a hundred years. ISIS killed people last week.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, here we go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I heard --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Today in Manila.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Today in Manila, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- celebrities. None of these celebrities, OK. Second thing is, if these celebrities really want to walk the walk, let's see them talk the talk. Give up the mansions on the coast, give up the private jets, give up the Gas-Guzzling SUVs.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then merely bike to work. Because I bet one celebrity puts out more carbon emissions than 100 Trump voters.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And, I would love to see --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh my gosh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- a celebrity take in a little coal mining family from West Virginia --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So the resentment against the elites.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You should put off another work, coal mining family in your five- story duplex --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: My man check, my man --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- Juan's place, OK. Let them live there for --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Your argument --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- because you're putting amount of work.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Your argument is --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- is resentment against elite. That's your argument, thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You are an elite, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, you think?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh my gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And let the celebrity (inaudible) --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm an aspiring elite.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: (Inaudible) to be a core that the Chinese actually will increase emissions until 2030. I mean, you can't even make the stuff up. Directly ahead, Hillary Clinton's blame-game tour, well, it continues. Wait until you hear what she said tonight, after this break.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Remember election night when Hillary Clinton stood up her supporters waiting for hours and hours at the Javits Center to console them and concede? It took a half a year. But today, Clinton finally made it to the site and chose to whine yet again about her crushing defeat, while continuing to take shots at her former political opponent.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I am particularly concerned about the role that Russia played and the very serious interference that we know they were responsible for in our most fundamental democratic act. When we look at the way that this White House is behaving about some of the biggest challenges we face, the dishonesty and fabrication and whether you call it fake news or lies, pick your choice, it is deeply troubling.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She's been on quite a bitter tour these days. Here's just a short list of some of the targets of her supposed blame. Basically everyone and anything but her.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Netflix.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What about --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why Netflix?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- content, forms and Macedonia. You know what that means.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We've got FBI, James Comey --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I didn't know what that mean.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- the Russians, Vladimir Putin --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She left off her husband.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- anti-Americans, excuses, low information voters, remember them?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Kimberly, if you were ever to play a drinking game and take a shot every time Hillary made an excuse for losing, you'd be hammered in about 10 minutes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I don't think I'm playing that game. That's a very dangerous game for me to play. But speaking of like bitter clingers, who's the bitter clingers now?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right? Still just holding on, can't let it go. We lost. Want to blame everybody and its like pin the tail on the clinger. Which one of them are they say is the one that sticks that they can finally rest assured that they can blame the entire election on, right? This is what's happening. She can't handle it. She's super upset but I think she's blowing it with her supporters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know who else interfered in the election? The Chinese in the 1996 Clinton re-election campaign when they funneled all that shady dough into the DNC and Hillary's coffers. She must know something about that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, remember, she's on this tour partly because she is selling her book, pre-sales, as she got millions of dollars for a book that's coming out this fall so she is at this -- they eventually is out today. It's called -- basically before the expo (ph). So she comes in and she previews it for all of the booksellers so that they'll buy a lot of books so she can hopefully sell a lot of books. One of my favorite quotes from a presidential autobiography was, in decision point, when President Bush wrote, "self-pity is a pathetic quality in a leader." And I had a former senior advisor of hers e-mailed me last night and he said, "it simply the most embarrassing I've ever seen her, filled with unsubstantiated conspiracy theories that really were borderline crazy. It's a complete denial of our democracy. I don't know the point. Sanders people don't trust her. Trump supporters hate her. So she keeps sinking below Trump and she isn't reaching out to people and still they think that she actually believe that she might be able to run again."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wait, who e-mailed that to you, Bill Clinton?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: President Clinton

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I was thinking.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Believe me, I'm not getting a call from anybody at 8:00 a.m.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well Juan, Hillary also blamed the DNC, Democratic National Committee, for losing. Now, didn't the DNC rigged the primary against Bernie? Wasn't that enough --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know about rigged but I think - -

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's what the e-mails show.

utterances.speaker: WILLIANS
utterances.utterance: You know, no, what the e-mail show was that they thought that she was the better candidate. That they had an interest in Hillary --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, no, there was --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- that's why they all protested at the DNC in Philly about it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, they thought --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- they had the --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The DNC Wasserman Schultz and that whole gang thought she was the better candidate. You know what strikes me in this conversation is, so much of what she says is true.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh my god.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And I was like, amazing. People say oh, it's whiny. It's whiny - -

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, so you agree with that entire list we saw?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, but I'm saying how can you say it's whiny that the Russians influenced the election? That's the truth. How can you say it's whiny when, you know, Gallup did a poll and said --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- contents, forms and Macedonia.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- when you put in Hillary Clinton's name, and this I got from Jessica Tarlov who wrote this piece for foxnews.com. It says the words e- mail lie and her came up, not president, not capable, not best for (INAUDIBLE) to do the job. This is the influence that people -- and you say, oh, this is too whiny.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Facebook and Google now rigged it against Hillary. Greg, would you like to respond?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you remember that story about that mayor, I think it was in Tennessee, that ran for office and won and he was dead at the time? He was a better candidate than her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ouch.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That you could say --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He blamed him for --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That they could say that some of these things are true but nothing will be more true than the fact that she was an awful candidate.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Correct. It's horrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now Trump may call you names and he may not like you but no one will ever think less of you than Hillary Clinton. Her whole life is about getting away from the ravel whereas Trump decided to embrace every man and every woman. Think about like, you know, people are criticizing Donald Trump over the Paris accords. Hillary pollutes the air because she wanted to a separate plane. She didn't want to fly with Michelle Obama to Betty Ford's funeral so she preferred to use her own plane. That's worse than anything Trump has done. Maybe she could have been a good president. The fact is, she's the queen of victimhood and her performance shows you that she would still cling, bitterly cling to identity driven politics. And it would affect all of her decision-making, nothing will change. She has embraced a dying ideology. She's kind of pathetic and sad.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, she blamed everybody. People --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- misogynist, suburban women -- Democrats making bad documentaries.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, Michael Moore didn't do enough. OK, when we come back, Greg, has some advice for one of President Trump's fiercest critics. Stay tuned.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you baby. Hooray, George Will wrote a new column! It's called "Conservatism is soiled by scowling primitives." He writes, "Today, conservativoism is soiled by scowling primitives whose irritable gestures lack mental ingredients. America needs a reminder of conservatism before vulgarians hijacked it." Fair enough, but should one engage hijacked conservatives by calling the people that they might support "scowling primitives"? Something tells me isn't about George giving advice, but flexing his intellectual muscles. Anyway, I'm seeing a lot of this. Conservatives go after Trump and his supporters often using a tone of knowing mockery. It's not that you're wrong but you're also stupid. You know who else does this? Trump apostles. Yesterday Corey Lewandowski said this:

utterances.speaker: CORESY LEWANDOWSKY, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN MANAGER
utterances.utterance: It's very simple, you know, President Trump was elected to change the country and you can get on board that train or you can lose your next election.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Get on that train, and who could forget this doozy?

utterances.speaker: OMAROSA MANIGAULT, TRUMP POLITICAL AIDE
utterances.utterance: Every critic, every dertractor will have to bow down to President Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Anyway, so here you have two sides within the same party battling over who's going to be right when this is all over. But we know the truth as always is in between. A Never Trumper is right on many of Trump's flaws. A Trump apostle is right that the president needs support. A Never Trumper is wrong to think Trump isn't trying to do right by Americans. A Trump apostle is wrong to deny serious obvious mistakes. Fact is, sticking to one perception creates a forced purity of thought that blinds you to realities which then keeps you from offering constructive criticism that might help a leader who actually could use it. So never say never and stop saying always. History shows that lockstep is always a march to disaster. At least I can say that today, the Never Trumpers and pro Trumpers united under the -- over the lefty meltdown.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, Matt Dawson (ph) tweeted that. It showed the picture of, you know, during World War I where like, let's just stop for Christmas and everyone like laughed. No one likes a scold, right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the scolding is getting out of hand but they're also missing the real point, which is I think also what you're saying, that it's not a matter of intellectual style ora matter of basically just getting on the train. The hard work is actually about a strategy and then trying to get it done. So, there's a lot that they want to do together, health care reform, tax reform, infrastructure plans, et cetera, that it just takes a lot of granular work. So grand gestures like the filibuster to shut down government because of Obamacare to try to repeal it, like those things don't actually work.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The good news for President Trump is that the majority of Republican (INAUDIBLE) is like 89 percent are with him on the policies. So now, like, the time to put the shoulder behind the --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Whatever the thing --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That thing on the football field.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know what it is. Hey Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sports analogy --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: My sports analogies are so bad. You haven't been --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, you pick winning teams.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, I want to ask you because I enjoyed George Will's writing. Sometimes it's hard to understand.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You got to read it twice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think he likes the thesaurus a lot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But anyway --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I like it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- I feel like I enjoy his writing but I don't think he's actually trying to convince anyone anymore. I think right now he is just kind of like firing the arrows and enjoying the strange new respect from liberals when he does it. Is that fair to say?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's on with him a lot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You said what?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You have been on air with him a lot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I like George, but I think this is interesting because, you know, usually, when you're dealing with conservatives, the argument would be that it's the left that's elitist. But now in this moment, here is George Will, who is I think an inheritor to William F. Buckley and that legacy of conservatism in America saying in fact, that he thinks that that legacy is being hurt.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I disagree. He's definitely no William F. Buckley.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I said an inheritor.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, but Buckley would get in and sit and argue and fight.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He'd get down and dirty. George Will is above that. He doesn't even wear jeans.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think George will fight -- I know he will fight with me. I don't know about you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think he fought with O'Reilly once.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: One time and done.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I will say this, that if you look at the numbers right now, you see that President Trump's numbers are going down with Republicans. I think he's down to about 80 percent. But it's even farther down with conservatives who say, you know, I'm not sure about Trump and young people. I think now about a quarter of young people who were identified as Republicans leave. Something's going on there, but it could be that people are uncomfortable.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But then why did the other polls show that people who supported President Trump in the election, 96 percent, said they would vote for him again.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well no, 80 percent, and in fact Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York said, I think yesterday, he thinks there's a 55 percent chance that Trump would get reelected.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think he's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Eight years of Trump, Juan, what are you going to do?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I said before that, you know, Jesus take the wheel.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Listen, George Will has never been on board with the whole situation. He was a very strong and vocal critic of President Trump, candidate Trump, you know, from day one. So, I don't find this to be that surprising.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And there were consequences for him for taking that (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYL
utterances.utterance: There were.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I think there's room in the Republican Party for the George Wills, for the nationalists, for the Bushes where we've had Eisenhower as a general. We've had an actor who is president. We've had now a mogul president so I mean, things evolve. The country wants different things. I don't think it helps when you have someone in the party saying the people that put your president in office are vulgarians or barbarians.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think it's OK if a party moves the president to the left or moves him to right, but this doesn't help at all. I think, you know, securing the border is civilized. I think protecting American jobs from going overseas is civilized and compassionate. I don't see anything vulgar about that at all. I'd like everybody to be able to come together for the next two years to pass in legislation and make sure people have money. So I think that's what they need to do and I think there's room for cooperation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, well on that upbeat note, new development in the Russia investigation. This time it might be bad news for Obama's top advisors. Details, when we return.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The House Intel Committee yesterday issued more subpoenas in the Russia investigation. The committee specifically looking into unmasking requests from three former Obama administration officials, Susan Rice, John Brennan and Samantha Power. President Trump tweeted today, "The big story is the unmasking and surveillance of people that took place during the Obama administration." Now, there were also subpoenas issued that had to do with the Russia investigation but the surprise is these four and coming from, Kimberly, Devon Nunez, who I thought had taken a step back but it looks like Devin Nunez is still a player.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think this is a huge story. I'm not sure why it hasn't gotten more coverage to be honest because it's something I think that's very significant. That should be something it grabs the attention of all Americans in terms of a privacy grab and surveillance which is, you know, one of the basic things that we hold near to our hearts and dear in this country. We fought for our liberty, our freedoms, our privacy rights. And here we've seen, you know, evidence, suggestion that this actually has occurred. So, I think it's important that they conduct the investigation and really get to the bottom of this and it can't just be swept away with just an inordinate amount of focus on Russia collusion with so far we have no evidence of.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, what do you think? You have Jim Comey now saying his testimony is going to come next Thursday, but you have this ongoing effort and it looks like this is what President Trump believes is as he says the big story, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think Democrats are going to regret these investigations because it might boomerang on them and, you know, I think the Russian thing is going to hurt them. Look, if Susan Rice, Brennan, and now Samantha Power, I mean, she's not even at all affiliated with the intelligence community so what was she doing submitting unmasking requests? So remember, there's paperwork for each unmasking request. They're going to, under oath, asked them why'd you do it. If they take the fifth, if they perjure themselves or they give some sort of partisan reason or unmasking these Trump people and then were disseminating classified information, we have a full-blown political spying scandal on our hands and that's a big deal.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Don't be surprised if they --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it would be a political scandal if they were using it for political purposes, but Dana, the contrary point of view is oh, then they find out why? They made these unmasking requests and it could be that then that implicates some of Trump's associates.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. So the hard thing about talking about this every night is that there is a fact-finding mission underway and we don't really have any of them so, I would like to just let that fact finding mission continue for them to answer questions on all (INAUDIBLE) procedures for unmasking, where they properly followed? What were the reasons why and let's just get answers to all of it. And I do wonder -- I do think the Nunes thing is bizarre because if you say you're going to take a step back and then you're issuing subpoenas without talking to your partisan counterpart, in this case the Democrats, I do think that that is a little strange.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What do you think? Is this more explosive than the Russia stuff, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know, subpoena is such a funny word.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I can't spell it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't spell it and when I say it I always feel dirty.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Really.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's what I thought about it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's your state of mind.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. By the way, this story seems so last month. It's like, you know, I hear the name Devin Nunes and I go like, who is that? That was only like two months ago, but in this --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Maybe that's why he issued the subpoenas.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Now you'll remember.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What subpoenas?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They remember my name.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What subpoenas?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh my gosh. Let's get out of here, now! "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Time now for "One More Thing." Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's just go right now. I hate these people! All right, you know what this is? Show them. Just show it. It is antidiarrheal medication.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my god, what is wrong with you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
